ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was exposed to Anthropology for the first time and had a lot of fun learning about the field.

This was my first anthropology class, and it was a great introduction into learning how to think critically, especially in regards to topics that were more complex. While I came from a science background, I had never thought about the social aspect behind health and medicine a and this class was really eye-opening, and allowed me to get a deeper understanding into the why behind medicine and health.
Health, medicine, disease, health systems, infrastructure, government, power, politics, and people in the Middle East; learning how to write and discuss complex matters in a concise way
I did not know much about Middle Eastern studies. By taking this class, I was enlightened of many concepts, ideas, and experiences many people face living in Middle Eastern countries!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very good syllabus with a wonderful professor

The class was great! The only weakness I would say, would be maybe to incorporate more power points or presentations since the majority of classes were simply discussion based. However, I loved how the class was mainly student lead and allowed for a wide array of opinion to be heard.

Strengths: covers very broad range of topics related to health and politics in the Middle East; reviews material broadly and deeply; class discussion facilitated to encourage safe and open conversations
Biggest strength: Dr. Berk!
Weakeness: some weeks had heavy set of readings that could get boring and could be cut

This class had many strengths! It was seminar based, and the class was really small, so it was easy to connect with the professor and other peers. The only weakness is that because it was small, it can be hard to participate especially if you are shy.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! This is a great introduction to anthropology and works well for all students interested whether their interest in health/medicine, politics, and everything in between. Dr. Berk is a FANTASTIC professor and its so sad shell be leaving Yale. She made students feel so confident and welcome in her class, and this class was one of the few spaces on campus were students could confidently come to class ready to have conversation with their peers and not feel anxious about their knowledge level or skill. Learned a ton about the topic and have a ton to take away for other classes!
Yes! This class has been one of the best classes I have taken here. I loved the professor and they always gave us amazing and easy to engage readings!
